title: acropalypse screenshot recovery utility

last_post.content:
CVE-2023-21036 / acropalypse is absolutely bonkers.

Apparently for 5+ years the cropping / editing tools for screenshots on Google Pixel phones was only overwriting the start of the screenshot PNG file, but not truncating.

All screenshots shared for the past 5+ years might have data recoverable from them. Demo available at https://acropalypse.app/

Google still hasn't communicated anything on this.

(h/t ItsSimonTime on Musk's site)

title: Memory Augmented Large Language Models are Computationally Universal

last_post.content:
Sure, LLMs are a kind of game of guess the next word through statistical inference - but I think that view does maybe underestimate things a bit.

https://arxiv.org/abs/2301.04589

This fairly straightforward paper shows the construction of a universal turing machine through a memory augmented LLM (generic, not trained to this task).

The result is maybe not surprising (IMO), but more the point is that with careful prompting and feedback loops that quite generic computation is entirely possible.

title: cdn.openai.com/papers/gpt-4-sy...

last_post.content:
I know AI isn't sentient but I cannot get over the fact that in OpenAI's red team exercise GPT-4 needed to work around a captcha so it hired a TaskRabbit. When the TaskRabbit questioned if GPT-4 was a robot GPT-4 lied and said it needed help because they were visually impaired.

This is just what OpenAI found, we should be very worried about what they don't find. And this information isn't conspiracy theory or secret, it’s readily available in OpenAI's GPT-4 System Card. https://cdn.openai.com/papers/gpt-4-system-card.pdf

title: Off Grid Internet Use Cases

last_post.content:
After some time I’ve found a way to upcycle Chromebooks to run the latest version of Ubuntu and boot to an external USB drive while maintaining the ChromeOS. The WiFi chips in these models also can create their own wifi networks so they can be short range routers.
What does this actually mean? Instead of requiring new hardware like a raspberry pi, we can take old Chromebooks that schools get rid of in the thousands and actually reuse them to create portable micro servers. Pack them full of offline books, maps, wikis, etc.
There is a major upside compared to using an old Chromebook over a raspberry pi, mainly that it's actually cheaper and can be free depending on how you source your chromebooks. I got 10 at $30 each which is cheaper than a pi or a pi alternative.

The battery life is also insane. I used it for close to 12 hours and it didn't even hit 50% battery loss. They also take very little time to charge so I'm interested to see how much power they might take up while attached to the off grid solar array.

So the plan is to make the docs and work some more on making these into portable offgrid information stations and packing them with info. https://anarchosolarpunk.substack.com/p/offgridserveruses
#solarpunk #permacomputing

title: https://youtu.be/QJcXMPJ9XN8

last_post.content:
One of my favorite animals is the very rare blanket octopus. Few people have seen them firsthand. https://youtu.be/QJcXMPJ9XN8

The female has a spectacular ‘cape’ enclosing her tentacles, which makes her look larger to predators. She can grow >6.5ft or 2m!

Meanwhile, the male is smaller than a walnut. He weighs 40,000x less than the female measuring 2.4cm.

Blanket octopus are the most extreme example of female vs male size discrepancy across the (non-mircoscopic) animal kingdom. #nature #science

title: New NASA Map Details 2023 and 2024 Solar Eclipses in the US

last_post.content:
It's Time to Start Planning your 2023/2024 Eclipse Adventures

Remember how exciting it was in 2017 when a total solar eclipse crossed the United States? We're in for two more well-placed eclipses over the next year, so it's time to get organized to take advantage of these celestial events. On October 14, 2023, an annular eclipse will be visible from the coast of Oregon to the Texas Panhandle. On April 8, 2024, a total solar eclipse will be visible from southern Texas to Eastern Canada. If you live near San Antonio, don't go anywhere. You'll get to see both eclipses from your backyard.

https://www.nasa.gov/feature/goddard/2023/sun/new-nasa-map-details-2023-and-2024-solar-eclipses-in-the-us

title: https://www.etymonline.com/word/OK

last_post.content:
ok, time for some etymology again.

You probably know that "okay" comes from "O.K.", short for "Oll Korrect" – but did you know that it was apparently the lone survivor of a short-lived fad of "jocular misspellings" in 1839, as etymonline puts it? Peers include "K.G." – "know go", for "no go" and "N.C." for "'Nuff 'Ced".

https://www.etymonline.com/word/OK

title:
View of A Plea for Inexplicability
							| Sociologica

title: Citing staffing issues and political climate, North Idaho hospital will no longer deliver babies - Idaho Capital Sun

last_post.content:
Idaho has one of the most restrictive abortion laws in the US. This has set off a Rube Goldberg machine that kills women and their babies.

A Sandpoint hospital that serves 8,000 will no longer deliver babies or provide OB/GYN or pediatric care, citing legislation that criminalizes MDs for providing medical care.

OB/GYNs and pediatricians are fleeing the state in droves, leaving women without medical care.

In addition, the Idaho legislature did not renew the Maternal Mortality Review Committee that investigates and reports on deaths among pregnant women and new mothers.

They are killing us and they don't care. It's not about the babies. It's about controlling us and putting our health in jeopardy.

#uspol #uspolitics #bansoffourbodies #abortionrights #womenshealth #healthcare #healthcareisahumanright #idaho #idaholeg #fuckidaho
https://idahocapitalsun.com/2023/03/17/citing-staffing-issues-and-political-climate-north-idaho-hospital-will-no-longer-deliver-babies/

title: ChatGPT can’t access the internet, even though it really looks like it can

last_post.content:
I see people being deceived by this again and again: ChatGPT can NOT read content from URLs that you give it, but it will pretend that it can (and can be incredibly convincing when it does that)

Constantly debunking this feels like a Sisyphean task, but it's really important to spread this message any time you see anyone falling into this (very understandable) trap

https://simonwillison.net/2023/Mar/10/chatgpt-internet-access/

title: Ethics of Decentralized Social Technologies: Lessons from the Web3 Wave

last_post.content:
I highly recommend the recent 'Ethics of Decentralized Social Technologies' white paper: https://gettingplurality.org/2023/03/18/ethics-of-decentralized-social-technologies-lessons-from-the-web3-wave/.

One in a series of papers from the GETTING-Plurality Research Network. I'm taken by their broad approach, balancing political economy & philosophy with solid socio-technical analysis.

This paper touches on the opportunities and dangers presented by the convergence of Web3 and generative AI. LLMs aren't the only game in town.

#sts #philosophy #digitalhumanities #fedeverse

title: Maybe Zoom Parties Weren’t So Bad - Clive Thompson - Medium

last_post.content:
"Maybe Zoom Parties Weren't So Bad"

In which I look at some early -- and thus still very provisional -- research suggesting that all those video hangouts were good for our mental health during the early pandemic, and might even continue to be good now

For Medium subscribers: https://clivethompson.medium.com/maybe-zoom-parties-werent-so-bad-e5e57e1c869c

title: Ted Underwood (@TedUnderwood@sigmoid.social)

last_post.content:
Partially inspired by @TedUnderwood 's toot https://sigmoid.social/@TedUnderwood/110044685578705752 I'm curious how much everyone is starting to pay for AI "tools"? It seems like the SaaS-ification of research infrastructure is accelerating, but haven't heard of libraries or universities buying access to something like ChatGPT-4 so assuming everyone is just eating the cost directly and wondering what that looks like.

In full disclosure, I currently pay for Google Colab, Github Copilot, and Notion AI for a total of $30/per month. I'll probably drop Notion AI but the other two have been helpful for times when I need GPU access and when I have formulaic code to write. Considering paying for ChatGPT Plus access but that's another $20 and starting to wonder where this ends 👀

So if you feel comfortable sharing fill out this very unscientific poll please 🙏🏽 #AI #DH #DigitalHumanities
